description: From Middle English lumpe, from a Germanic base akin to Proto-Germanic *limpaną (“to glide, go, hang loosely”). Compare Dutch lomp (“rag”), German Low German Lump (“rag”), German Lumpen (“rag”) and Lump (“ragamuffin”).

entries.meaning: Something that protrudes, sticks out, or sticks together; a cluster or blob; a mound or mass of no particular shape.
examples: Stir the gravy until there are no more lumps.
a lump of coal; a lump of clay; a lump of cheese

entries.meaning: A swelling or nodule of tissue under the skin or in an internal part of the body.

examples: The money arrived all at once as one big lump sum payment.

entries.meaning: A small, shaped mass of sugar, typically about a teaspoonful.
examples: Do you want one lump or two with your coffee?
Don't just sit there like a lump.

entries.meaning: (informal, as plural) A beating or verbal abuse.
examples: He's taken his lumps over the years.

entries.meaning: A projection beneath the breech end of a gun barrel.
A kind of fish, the lumpsucker.
(obsolete, slang) Food given to a tramp to be eaten on the road.
examples: “A lump,” explained The Whimperer  […]  “is wot a kin’ lady slips youse w’en youse batter de back door. If she invites youse in and lets youse t’row yer feet unner de table, it’s a set-down. If she slips youse a lunch in a poiper bag, it’s a lump. See?  […] ”

verbs.description: lump (third-person singular simple present lumps, present participle lumping, simple past and past participle lumped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat as a single unit; to group together in a casual or chaotic manner (as if forming an ill-defined lump of the items).
examples: People tend to lump turtles and tortoises together, when in fact they are different creatures.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bear (a heavy or awkward burden); to carry (something unwieldy) from one place to another.
examples: Well, a male body was brought to a certain surgeon by a man he had often employed, and the pair lumped it down on the dissecting table, and then the vendor received his money and went.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To burden (someone) with an undesired task or responsibility.
(transitive, slang) To hit or strike (a person).
examples: If that's the only way you can fight, then you'd better be prepared to get lumped.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To form a lump or lumps.
examples: Thin the paint with mineral spirits for a medium consistency so that it will not drip or lump.
